channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [OAK-3991] Incorrect resultset from XPATH, multiple ORs and Lucene full-text
item.description:
In case of more complex xpath queries with a mix of ORs, ANDs and
full-text the returned resultset is wrong. Some of the conditions are
lost during the query execution. Most probably during the Filter
creation.

The query is:

/jcr:root/test//element(*, nt:unstructured)[ 
  (
    jcr:contains(., 'cinema') 
    or @tags = 'architecture-keywords:building/cinema' 
    or @tags = '/tags/architecture-keywords/building/cinema' 
  ) 
  and @status = 'amber' 
  and ( 
    not(@id) 
    and ( not(@types) 
    or (
      not(@types = 'published') 
      and not(@types = 'page') 
      and not(@types = 'asset') 
    ) 
  )
)]

In this case if you replace the @tags conditions with a
jcr:contains rather than = it will make the query works. Which
suggests the same root cause of OAK-2660.

OAK-2660 was indirectly addressed by OAK-1617 but the OR->UNION
conversion is not applied to subqueries of a UNION set.

See attached patch for a reproducing test case.
item.summary: Incorrect resultset from XPATH, multiple ORs and Lucene full-text

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Created a branch as well for experimenting around with it https://github.com/davidegiannella/jackrabbit-oak/tree/OAK-3991

Which suggests the same root cause of OAK-2660.

I think we'd need to figure out the root cause this time. Here's the translated sql from the xpath query in test case (indented for clarity):

select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], * from [nt:unstructured] as a where
[types] is null
and [status] = 'amber' and isdescendantnode(a, '/test') and [id] is NULL
and contains(*, 'cinema')

union

select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], * from [nt:unstructured] as a where
[types] is null
and [status] = 'amber' and isdescendantnode(a, '/test') and [id] is null
and [tags] in('architecture-keywords:building/cinema', '/tags/architecture-keywords/building/cinema')

union

select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], * from [nt:unstructured] as a where
isdescendantnode(a, '/test') and [id] is null and [status] = 'amber'
and (   contains(*, 'cinema')      or     [tags] in('architecture-keywords:building/cinema', '/tags/architecture-keywords/building/cinema')    )
and not([types] = 'published') and not([types] = 'page') and not([types] = 'asset')

The plan for this query came up as:

[nt:unstructured] as [a]
/* lucene:test-index(/oak:index/test-index) +(full:title:cinema :fulltext:cinema) +:ancestors:/test ft:("cinema") where
([a].[types] is null)
and ([a].[status] = 'amber') and (isdescendantnode([a], [/test])) and ([a].[id] is null)
and (contains([a].[*], 'cinema'))
*/

union

[nt:unstructured] as [a]
/* lucene:test-index(/oak:index/test-index) +:ancestors:/test +(tags:architecture-keywords:building/cinema tags:/tags/architecture-keywords/building/cinema) where
([a].[types] is null)
and ([a].[status] = 'amber') and (isdescendantnode([a], [/test])) and ([a].[id] is null)
and ([a].[tags] in('architecture-keywords:building/cinema', '/tags/architecture-keywords/building/cinema'))
*/

union

[nt:unstructured] as [a]
/* lucene:test-index(/oak:index/test-index) :ancestors:/test where
(isdescendantnode([a], [/test])) and ([a].[id] is null) and ([a].[status] = 'amber')
*/

The interesting part is how the 3rd query in union is planned. The planned query of 3rd section loses second and third line of sql2 version. To eloborate:

select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], * from [nt:unstructured] as a where
isdescendantnode(a, '/test') and [id] is null and [status] = 'amber'
and (   contains(*, 'cinema')      or     [tags] in('architecture-keywords:building/cinema', '/tags/architecture-keywords/building/cinema')    )
and not([types] = 'published') and not([types] = 'page') and not([types] = 'asset')

v/s

[nt:unstructured] as [a]
/* lucene:test-index(/oak:index/test-index) :ancestors:/test where
(isdescendantnode([a], [/test])) and ([a].[id] is null) and ([a].[status] = 'amber')
*/

Since, lost clauses are for and this time, so I don't think switching to union might help. I tried to track down how the ast is formed but I got totally lost. Hope the observations helps .

The conversion from XPath to SQL-2 seems to be buggy in this case. A simpler example:

/jcr:root/test//*[ 
  (
    jcr:contains(., 'cinema') or @tags = 1
  ) 
  and ( 
   ( not(@a) 
    or (
      @types = 'a'
      and @types = 'b'
    ) 
  )
 )]

select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [a] is null
  and isdescendantnode(a, '/test')
  and contains(*, 'cinema')
  
  union select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [a] is null
  and isdescendantnode(a, '/test')
  and [tags] = 1
  
  union select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where isdescendantnode(a, '/test')
  and (contains(*, 'cinema')
  or [tags] = 1)
  and [types] = 'a'
  and [types] = 'b'

The "or" part in the last subquery is unexpected.

The conversion from XPath to SQL-2 seems to be buggy in this case

Just to confirm, you mean that it should have further got broken down into another UNION clause? (semantically, it seems correct to me)

I was wondering, btw, even if it didn't break down into 4 unions, is it expected to lose constraints from the 3rd query (non-further-broken-down-one)? Should that not be a bug as well?

Yes, semantically, the conversion is correct, but it should be converted to a union query without "or", so that the (Lucene) fullindex can be used. When the "or" condition is still there in the subquery, the fulltext index can't be used. Same for

/jcr:root//*[(@a=1 or @b=1) and (@c=2 or (@c=3 and @c=4))]

select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [c] = 2
  and isdescendantnode(a, '/')
  and [a] = 1
  union select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [c] = 2
  and isdescendantnode(a, '/')
  and [b] = 1
  union select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where isdescendantnode(a, '/')
  and ([a] = 1
  or [b] = 1)
  and [c] = 3
  and [c] = 4

This is without "contains" (without fulltext index). There should be no "or", instead 4 union subqueries should be used. What is strange is that by removing the path constraint, the conversion is correct:

//*[(@a=1 or @b=1) and (@c=2 or (@c=3 and @c=4))]

select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [c] = 2
  and [a] = 1
  union select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [c] = 2
  and [b] = 1
  union select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [c] = 3
  and [c] = 4
  and [a] = 1
  union select [jcr:path], [jcr:score], *
  from [nt:base] as a
  where [c] = 3
  and [c] = 4
  and [b] = 1

Please note that c can be both 3 and 4 at the same time, when using multi-valued properties.

thomasm

but it should be converted to a union query without "or", so that the (Lucene) fullindex can be used. When the "or" condition is still there in the subquery, the fulltext index can't be used

but this is the exactly the same case that OAK-1617 addressed for standard queries. Not union. Would it make sense to apply the same logic then a UnionQueryImpl? Asking therefore to find alternatives at the lowest layer (ast)?

The only setback I can see here is that if we then have to backport it, we should have to backport OAK-1617 as well which was quite a change on the query engine level providing even new API.

Or would it make sense to see if leveraging OAK-1617 on trunk and another approach on 1.2?

It should be fairly simple to test out the lowest level of optimisation (OAK-1617) and see if that would work.

The problem was that converting "or" conditions to "union" didn't always work, because moving "or" conditions to the right hand side of an "and" condition was broken in some (nested) cases. The logic (rotating the AST tree) was quite complex and broken, I tried to simplify and fix it. Possible patch (excluding tests):

--- src/main/java/org/apache/jackrabbit/oak/query/xpath/Expression.java	(revision 1727570)
+++ src/main/java/org/apache/jackrabbit/oak/query/xpath/Expression.java	(working copy)
@@ -477,27 +477,41 @@
                 return nt;
             }
             return right.getMostSpecificNodeType(selectorName);
-        }        
+        }
         
         @Override
         AndCondition pullOrRight() {
-            if (right instanceof OrCondition) {
-                return this;
-            } else if (left instanceof OrCondition) {
-                return new AndCondition(right, left);
+            ArrayList<Expression> list = getAllAndConditions();
+            OrCondition or = null;
+            Expression result = null;
+            for(Expression e : list) {
+                if (e instanceof OrCondition && or == null) {
+                    or = (OrCondition) e;
+                } else if (result == null) {
+                    result = e;
+                } else {
+                    result = new AndCondition(result, e);
+                }
+            }
+            if (or != null) {
+                result = new AndCondition(result, or);
+            }
+            return (AndCondition) result;
+        }
+        
+        private ArrayList<Expression> getAllAndConditions() {
+            ArrayList<Expression> list = new ArrayList<Expression>();
+            if (left instanceof AndCondition) {
+                list.addAll(((AndCondition) left).getAllAndConditions());
+            } else {
+                list.add(left);
             }
             if (right instanceof AndCondition) {
-                // pull up x:
-                // a and (b and (x)) -> (a and b) and (x)
-                AndCondition r2 = (AndCondition) right;
-                r2 = r2.pullOrRight();
-                AndCondition l2 = new AndCondition(left, r2.left);
-                l2 = l2.pullOrRight();
-                return new AndCondition(l2, r2.right);
-            } else if (left instanceof AndCondition) {
-                return new AndCondition(right, left).pullOrRight();
+                list.addAll(((AndCondition) right).getAllAndConditions());
+            } else {
+                list.add(right);
             }
-            return this;
+            return list;
         }
         
         @Override

didn't test the patch but by an overview looks ok. With regards of the test, the attached patch I put with the ticket should cover the case from a query point of view. Not the Expression specific change of logic.
http://svn.apache.org/r1729608 (fix, but only few new test cases)
for the actual backport see OAK-4324
